canonical_explanation.text: Every child has certain rights. Rights are things that every person deserves to have or do. The United Nations made a list of children's rights called the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. In India, children have important rights. The Right to Education (RTE) Act says that every child between the ages of 6 and 14 has the right to free education in a nearby school. This means no child can be denied the chance to go to school. Children also have the right to be safe, the right to good food and health, the right to play, and the right to be treated equally regardless of whether they are a boy or girl. Gender equality means boys and girls have equal rights and should be treated fairly. Girls have the same right to education, play, and opportunities as boys. No child should be treated unfairly because of their gender. Along with rights come responsibilities. Responsibilities are duties or things we should do. At home, responsibilities include helping with household chores, respecting elders, being kind to siblings, and keeping our room clean. At school, responsibilities include attending regularly, completing homework, following rules, respecting teachers and classmates, and keeping the classroom clean. In the community, responsibilities include not littering, following traffic rules, respecting public property, being kind to animals, and helping elderly people. When everyone follows their responsibilities, the community becomes a better and safer place for all.
rules: Rights are things every person deserves to have or do
The Right to Education (RTE) Act gives free education to children aged 6-14
Every child has the right to safety, food, health, and play
Gender equality means boys and girls have equal rights
Responsibilities are duties we should follow
Home responsibilities: help with chores, respect elders, keep room clean
School responsibilities: attend regularly, do homework, follow rules, respect others
Community responsibilities: no littering, follow traffic rules, respect public property

questions.question_text: What are rights?

options.text: Things every person deserves to have or do

questions.explanation_correct: Rights are things that every person deserves to have or do. For example, every child has the right to education, safety, food, health, and play. Rights are not bought or given as gifts — they belong to everyone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rights are not things we buy, gifts from friends, or toys. They are basic entitlements that every person deserves simply because they are human.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a right that every child in India has?

options.text: Right to stay up all night

questions.explanation_correct: Every child in India has the right to free education under the Right to Education (RTE) Act. Children aged 6 to 14 can go to a nearby school for free. This is a fundamental right.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Children cannot drive cars (too young). Staying up all night and eating only candy are not rights — they are unhealthy. Free education is a real, important right for every child.

questions.question_text: The Right to Education (RTE) Act says that free education is for children between the ages of:
questions.explanation_correct: The Right to Education (RTE) Act of 2009 states that every child between 6 and 14 years of age has the right to free and compulsory education in a neighbourhood school.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The RTE Act covers children aged 6 to 14 years, not 3-10, 10-18, or 5-12. This age range ensures all children can complete their elementary education for free.

questions.question_text: True or False: The Right to Education means every child can go to school for free.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Right to Education (RTE) Act guarantees free and compulsory education for every child between 6 and 14 years. No child should be denied education because their family cannot afford it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. The RTE Act does provide free education for all children aged 6-14 in government schools.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a right of every child?

options.text: Right to be safe from harm
Right to skip school whenever they want

questions.explanation_correct: Every child has the right to be safe from harm. This means children should be protected from violence, abuse, and exploitation. Skipping school, hitting others, and breaking things are not rights.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Skipping school, hitting others, and breaking things are not rights — they are wrong actions. The right to safety is a genuine right that protects every child from harm.

questions.question_text: Seema's parents do not want to send her to school because she is a girl. Is this right?

options.text: Yes, only boys need to go to school
No, every child, whether a boy or girl, has the right to education

questions.explanation_correct: No, it is not right. Every child — both boys and girls — has the equal right to education. The RTE Act does not discriminate based on gender. Denying education to a girl is against the law.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is absolutely wrong to deny a girl education. Both boys and girls have equal right to education. The law says every child aged 6-14 must get free education, regardless of gender.

questions.question_text: What does gender equality mean?

options.text: Boys and girls have equal rights and should be treated fairly
Boys and girls are exactly the same

questions.explanation_correct: Gender equality means that boys and girls have equal rights and should be treated fairly. Both deserve the same opportunities for education, play, safety, and all other rights.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gender equality is not about only boys or only girls having rights. It does not mean boys and girls are identical. It means they have equal rights and deserve fair treatment.

questions.question_text: True or False: Girls have the same right to play sports as boys.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Girls have the same right to play sports as boys. Gender equality means equal opportunities in all areas, including sports, education, and all other activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Girls absolutely have the same right to play sports as boys. Many Indian women have made the country proud in sports like cricket, badminton, wrestling, and boxing.

questions.question_text: In Ravi's class, the teacher says only boys can be class monitors. Is this fair?

options.text: Yes, only boys should be leaders
No, both boys and girls should have equal chance to be monitors

questions.explanation_correct: This is not fair. Both boys and girls should have an equal chance to be class monitors. Gender equality means giving equal opportunities to everyone, regardless of whether they are a boy or a girl.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is unfair to say only boys can be leaders. Girls can be excellent leaders too. Both boys and girls deserve equal opportunities in everything, including leadership roles.

questions.question_text: Priya wants to play football but some boys say 'football is only for boys.' What should Priya do?

options.text: Remember that she has equal right to play and should keep playing
Agree that only boys can play

questions.explanation_correct: Priya has every right to play football. Sports are for everyone, regardless of gender. India has many successful women footballers. Priya should remember her rights and keep playing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Priya should not give up, agree, or stop liking football. Boys and girls have equal rights to play any sport. Saying a sport is 'only for boys' or 'only for girls' is wrong.

questions.question_text: What are responsibilities?

options.text: Things we want but cannot have
Duties or things we should do

questions.explanation_correct: Responsibilities are duties or things we should do. They are actions we take to be a good person at home, school, and in the community. Rights and responsibilities go hand in hand.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Responsibilities are not wants, games, or subjects. They are duties — things we should do to be good members of our family, school, and community.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a responsibility at home?

options.text: Making a mess and not cleaning up
Helping with household chores and keeping your room clean

questions.explanation_correct: Helping with household chores and keeping your room clean is a responsibility at home. Being a responsible family member means helping out, respecting elders, and being kind to siblings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Watching TV all day, making messes, and being rude are not responsibilities. Helping with chores and keeping clean is being a responsible family member.

questions.question_text: Which is a responsibility at school?

options.text: Talking while the teacher is teaching

questions.explanation_correct: Completing homework and respecting teachers are important school responsibilities. Other school responsibilities include attending class regularly, following rules, and being kind to classmates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not doing homework, talking during lessons, and skipping classes are irresponsible behaviours. Completing homework and respecting teachers are proper school responsibilities.

questions.question_text: Which is a responsibility in the community?

options.text: Not littering and following traffic rules

questions.explanation_correct: Not littering and following traffic rules are important community responsibilities. Other community responsibilities include respecting public property, being kind to animals, and helping elderly people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing garbage, breaking property, and being rude are irresponsible actions. Not littering and following traffic rules are examples of being a responsible community member.

questions.question_text: True or False: Respecting elders is a responsibility at home.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Respecting elders is an important responsibility at home. In Indian culture, showing respect to parents, grandparents, and other elders is considered very important.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Respecting elders is indeed a responsibility at home and is an important part of Indian culture and values.

questions.question_text: After a picnic in the park, Amit's friends leave their wrappers on the ground. What should Amit do?

options.text: Pick up the wrappers and throw them in a dustbin

questions.explanation_correct: Amit should pick up the wrappers and throw them in a dustbin. Keeping public places clean is everyone's responsibility. He should also tell his friends not to litter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leaving wrappers, throwing more litter, or blaming others is irresponsible. Amit should clean up and encourage his friends to do the same. Keeping public spaces clean is a community responsibility.

questions.question_text: Which of these is BOTH a right and a responsibility?

options.text: Going to school — right to learn and responsibility to study well

questions.explanation_correct: Education is both a right and a responsibility. Every child has the RIGHT to go to school, and they also have the RESPONSIBILITY to attend regularly, study well, and complete their homework.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Watching TV, playing games, and eating junk food are neither important rights nor responsibilities. Education is the perfect example of something that is both a right and a responsibility.

questions.question_text: Rights and responsibilities are:

options.text: Connected — with every right comes a responsibility

questions.explanation_correct: Rights and responsibilities are connected. With every right comes a responsibility. For example, you have the right to education, but you also have the responsibility to study well. You have the right to play, but the responsibility to play fairly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rights and responsibilities are closely related. They are for everyone (children and adults, rich and poor). Every right comes with a matching responsibility.

questions.question_text: True or False: If you have the right to play in a park, you also have the responsibility to keep the park clean.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Rights and responsibilities go together. You have the right to enjoy public spaces like parks, but you also have the responsibility to keep them clean for others to enjoy too.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Every right comes with a corresponding responsibility. Enjoying public spaces comes with the duty to maintain them.

questions.question_text: Every child has the right to:

options.text: Good food, clean water, and healthcare

questions.explanation_correct: Every child has the right to good food, clean water, and healthcare. These are basic rights that help children grow healthy and strong. Children also have the right to protection from child labour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Children should not work (child labour is illegal). Staying up all night is unhealthy. Doing whatever you want is not a right. Good food, clean water, and healthcare are genuine children's rights.

questions.question_text: Which of the following shows gender equality?

options.text: Only boys are allowed in the science lab
Girls are not allowed to ride bicycles
Both boys and girls participate equally in all school activities
Only girls help in the kitchen

questions.explanation_correct: Gender equality means both boys and girls have equal access to all activities. When both participate equally in science, sports, arts, and all activities, that is true gender equality.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Restricting boys from labs, girls from bicycles, or assigning kitchen work only to girls are all examples of gender INequality. Equal participation by all is gender equality.

questions.question_text: Rina has a test tomorrow but wants to watch TV instead of studying. What should she do?

options.text: Watch TV because it is more fun
Study for the test because it is her responsibility as a student
Ask someone else to take the test for her

questions.explanation_correct: Rina should study for her test because preparing for exams is a student's responsibility. She has the right to education, and with that right comes the responsibility to study and do her best.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Watching TV, skipping the test, or cheating are all irresponsible choices. As a student, preparing for tests is an important responsibility.

questions.question_text: Which of these shows being responsible at school?

options.text: Being kind to classmates and doing your own work

questions.explanation_correct: Being kind to classmates and doing your own work shows responsibility at school. A responsible student treats others with respect and does honest work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bullying, copying homework, and running in corridors are irresponsible and can harm yourself or others. Being kind and doing your own work are signs of a responsible student.

questions.question_text: The __________ Act says every child aged 6-14 has the right to free education.
questions.explanation_correct: The Right to Education (RTE) Act of 2009 guarantees free and compulsory education to every child aged 6 to 14 years. It is one of the most important laws for children in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the Right to Play and Food are important, the specific act about free education is the Right to Education (RTE) Act.

questions.question_text: If everyone in a community follows their responsibilities, what happens?

options.text: The community becomes a better and safer place

questions.explanation_correct: When everyone follows their responsibilities — not littering, following rules, respecting others, and helping those in need — the community becomes a better, safer, and happier place for everyone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Following responsibilities does change things for the better. It does not make people selfish. It benefits everyone, not just some. Responsible behaviour makes the whole community better.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a right of children?
questions.explanation_correct: Bullying others is NOT a right. In fact, bullying violates other children's right to safety and dignity. Education, safety, and healthcare are genuine rights of every child.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Education, safety, and healthcare are real children's rights. Bullying is not a right — it is harmful behaviour that violates the rights of others.

questions.question_text: Which statement about gender equality is TRUE?

options.text: Only boys should go to school
Girls cannot become doctors or engineers
Both boys and girls deserve equal opportunities in education and work
Only girls should do household work

questions.explanation_correct: Gender equality means both boys and girls deserve equal opportunities in education, careers, sports, and all areas of life. Many Indian women are successful doctors, engineers, scientists, and leaders.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saying only boys should go to school, girls cannot be professionals, or only girls should do housework are all examples of gender discrimination. Both genders deserve equal opportunities.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a responsibility at home, school, AND in the community?

options.text: Being kind and respectful to others

questions.explanation_correct: Being kind and respectful to others is a responsibility everywhere — at home (with family), at school (with teachers and classmates), and in the community (with neighbours and strangers).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Homework is specific to school. Cooking is at home. Children don't drive. Being kind and respectful is a universal responsibility that applies at home, school, and in the community.

questions.question_text: True or False: Both boys and girls should help with household chores.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Gender equality applies at home too. Both boys and girls should help with household chores like cleaning, setting the table, and tidying up. No chore is 'only for boys' or 'only for girls'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Household chores are everyone's responsibility. Both boys and girls should learn to help around the house equally.

questions.question_text: Karan says, 'I have the right to play, so I don't need to study.' Is he correct?

options.text: Yes, he can play all the time
No, he has the right to play but also the responsibility to study

questions.explanation_correct: Karan is wrong. While he does have the right to play, he also has the responsibility to study. Rights and responsibilities go together. A good balance of study and play is important.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Playing all the time is not right. Studying IS important. Children should play AND study. Rights come with responsibilities — the right to play must be balanced with the responsibility to study.

questions.question_text: An 8-year-old child is working in a factory instead of going to school. What right is being violated?
questions.explanation_correct: The child's right to education is being violated. Under the RTE Act, every child aged 6-14 should be in school, not working. Child labour (children working in factories) is illegal in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A right IS being violated. It is not about TV. While the right to play is also affected, the most important right being violated is the right to education. Every child deserves to go to school.

questions.question_text: Meena sees an elderly person trying to cross a busy road. What should she do?

options.text: Help the person cross the road safely

questions.explanation_correct: Meena should help the elderly person cross the road safely. Helping elderly people is a community responsibility. Being kind and helpful to others, especially those who need help, makes the community better.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ignoring, laughing, or running away are unkind and irresponsible. Helping elderly people is a community responsibility. A responsible citizen helps those in need.

questions.question_text: __________ means boys and girls have equal rights and should be treated fairly.
questions.explanation_correct: Gender equality means boys and girls have equal rights and should be treated fairly. It means giving both genders the same opportunities and respect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Competition, punishment, and homework are not about equal rights for boys and girls. Gender equality is the term for equal rights and fair treatment for all genders.

questions.question_text: Which pair correctly matches a right with its corresponding responsibility?

options.text: Right to education — Responsibility to break school property
Right to play — Responsibility to play fairly and share
Right to food — Responsibility to waste food
Right to safety — Responsibility to hurt others

questions.explanation_correct: The right to play comes with the responsibility to play fairly and share. Breaking property, wasting food, and hurting others are the OPPOSITE of responsible behaviour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Breaking property, wasting food, and hurting others are wrong actions, not responsibilities. The right to play paired with the responsibility to play fairly is the correct match.

questions.question_text: The United Nations made a special list of rights for children called the:

options.text: UN Convention on the Rights of the Child

questions.explanation_correct: The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC) is a special document that lists the rights of every child worldwide. India has agreed to follow this convention, ensuring all children's rights are protected.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Game Book, World Food Programme, and Olympic Charter are not about children's rights. The UNCRC (UN Convention on the Rights of the Child) specifically lists children's rights.

questions.question_text: Following traffic rules is a responsibility in the:
questions.explanation_correct: Following traffic rules is a community responsibility. When we are on roads, we must follow traffic signals, use crosswalks, and be careful — this keeps everyone safe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Traffic rules apply in the community (on roads and streets), not in classrooms, kitchens, or bathrooms. It is a community responsibility that keeps everyone on the road safe.

questions.question_text: True or False: Child labour is a violation of children's rights.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Child labour (making children work instead of go to school) is a serious violation of children's rights. In India, child labour is illegal. Every child should be in school, not in a factory or workplace.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Child labour violates children's right to education, safety, and a healthy childhood. It is illegal in India.

questions.question_text: Sonal's brother says she cannot study science because 'science is for boys only.' What should Sonal know?

options.text: Science is for everyone; many great Indian women are scientists
Only boys are good at science

questions.explanation_correct: Science is for everyone! Many great Indian women are scientists, like Kalpana Chawla (astronaut), Tessy Thomas (missile scientist), and many more. Sonal has every right to study science.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Her brother is wrong. Girls should never give up their dreams. Science is not 'just for boys'. India has many brilliant women scientists who have made the country proud.

questions.question_text: Which list contains ONLY responsibilities?

options.text: Do homework, respect teachers, keep surroundings clean
Watch TV, play games, eat ice cream
Go to school, take a vacation, celebrate birthday

questions.explanation_correct: Doing homework, respecting teachers, and keeping surroundings clean are all responsibilities. The other lists contain activities that are not duties or obligations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Playing, eating, sleeping, watching TV, and vacations are activities, not responsibilities. Only doing homework, respecting teachers, and keeping surroundings clean are true responsibilities.

questions.question_text: Aman has the right to use the school library. What is his responsibility when using it?

options.text: Take care of books, return them on time, and keep quiet

questions.explanation_correct: When using the library, Aman's responsibilities include taking care of books, returning them on time, and keeping quiet so others can read. Rights and responsibilities go together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tearing pages, shouting, running, and not returning books are all irresponsible. Using the library comes with the responsibility to treat books carefully and be considerate of others.

questions.question_text: Every child has the right to:
questions.explanation_correct: Every child has the right to play and have recreation (fun activities). Play is important for a child's physical and mental development. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child includes the right to play.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Children should not only work. Staying home forever limits learning. Not listening to anyone is not a right. The right to play and recreation is an important children's right.

questions.question_text: True or False: You can have rights without any responsibilities.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Rights and responsibilities go hand in hand. Every right comes with a responsibility. If you want to enjoy your rights, you must also fulfil your responsibilities towards others.
questions.explanation_incorrect: You cannot have rights without responsibilities. They are connected. For example, the right to education comes with the responsibility to study. The right to a clean environment comes with the responsibility not to litter.

questions.question_text: Which of these Indian women broke gender barriers and made India proud?

options.text: Kalpana Chawla — first Indian woman in space
No Indian woman has achieved anything great
Only men can make the country proud

questions.explanation_correct: Kalpana Chawla was the first Indian-origin woman to go to space. She is one of many Indian women who broke gender barriers. Others include PV Sindhu (badminton), Mary Kom (boxing), and Nirmala Sitharaman (finance minister).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many Indian women have achieved great things. Women can absolutely achieve greatness. Both men and women make the country proud. Kalpana Chawla is a shining example.

questions.question_text: Rohit's class has a rule: 'Keep the classroom clean.' This rule helps students learn about:
questions.explanation_correct: The classroom rule about cleanliness teaches students to take responsibility for their environment. When students keep their classroom clean, they learn that maintaining shared spaces is everyone's duty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A cleanliness rule is not about games, cooking, or swimming. It teaches responsibility — specifically, the responsibility to take care of shared spaces.

questions.question_text: Which statement BEST describes the relationship between rights and responsibilities?

options.text: Rights are important but responsibilities are not
Responsibilities are important but rights are not
Both rights and responsibilities are equally important and go together
Rights and responsibilities have nothing to do with each other

questions.explanation_correct: Both rights and responsibilities are equally important and go together. You cannot have one without the other. A good citizen knows their rights and also fulfils their responsibilities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neither rights nor responsibilities are more important than the other. They are not unrelated. Both are equally important and are closely connected — they go hand in hand.

questions.question_text: Being kind to animals is a __________ in the community.
questions.explanation_correct: Being kind to animals is a responsibility in the community. Animals deserve to be treated with care and kindness. We should not hurt, tease, or abandon animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Being kind to animals is not a game, punishment, or school subject. It is a responsibility — something we should do as caring members of our community.

questions.question_text: Lakshmi's family is very poor and cannot afford to send her to school. What does the law say?

options.text: Poor children do not need to go to school
Only rich children can go to school
The RTE Act says every child gets free education, regardless of family income

questions.explanation_correct: The RTE Act guarantees free education for every child aged 6-14, regardless of whether the family is rich or poor. Lakshmi has the right to go to a government school for free. No child should be denied education due to poverty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Poor children absolutely need and deserve education. Education is not only for the rich. Children should not work. The RTE Act provides free education for all children.

questions.question_text: True or False: Completing homework on time is a student's responsibility.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Completing homework on time is an important responsibility for every student. It helps reinforce what is learned in class and shows dedication to learning.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Homework completion is indeed a student's responsibility and is part of being a good learner.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of gender inequality?

options.text: Both boys and girls attending the same school
A girl being told she cannot become a pilot because she is a girl
Both boys and girls playing cricket together
A brother and sister both helping to wash dishes

questions.explanation_correct: Telling a girl she cannot become a pilot because of her gender is an example of gender inequality. Girls can be anything — pilots, doctors, engineers, scientists. Many Indian women are successful pilots.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boys and girls attending school together, playing together, and sharing chores are all examples of gender equality. Only denying a girl's dream because of gender is inequality.

questions.question_text: What happens when people enjoy their rights but do NOT follow their responsibilities?

options.text: The community becomes chaotic and problems arise
It does not matter at all

questions.explanation_correct: When people enjoy rights but ignore responsibilities, problems arise. For example, if everyone uses public parks (right) but no one keeps them clean (responsibility), parks become dirty and unusable. A balance of rights and responsibilities is essential.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ignoring responsibilities does not keep things perfect or lead to only good outcomes. It very much matters. Without responsibility, society becomes messy and unfair for everyone.
